newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: Argentine Congress passes revenue-boosting laws.
newsitem.headline: Argentine Congress passes revenue-boosting laws.

text.p: Argentina's lower house of Congress approved and passed on to the Senate Thursday a law reducing family allowance benefits and imposing a 14 percent tax to employers on widely-used food vouchers.

The government initiative launched in July by former Economy Minister Domingo Cavallo was approved in the Chamber of Deputies before dawn after a long debate, with substantial modifications to the original project.
Under the legislation, family allowance benefits would be scrapped for those earning above $1,500 a month, except for those who have handicapped children.

Workers earning up to $500 would get $40 in family allowances, those making up to $1,000 would get $30 and those earning up to $1,500 would receive $20. While the higher-income earners would lose their benefits under the bill, the lowest earners would receive more.
The president of the Social Program Committee in the Chamber of Deputies, Oraldo Britos, defended the law saying "it will benefit 90 percent of workers."
The other law passed by the Chamber of Deputies early Thursday is one imposing a levy on widely-used food vouchers that employers give workers as part of their pay packages.

Employers would now have to pay a 14 percent tax on the so-called luncheon tickets. The ruling Peronist Party wanted to apply a tax of only 10 percent on the tickets but caved in to pressure from the government, which needs the extra income.
The original project designed by Cavallo sought to cap family allowances at $1,000 and wanted to impose higher taxes on the food vouchers.
The measures, designed to boost revenue and savings to reduce a growing fiscal deficit, sparked widespread condemnation and provoked a general strike in August.
A few weeks after announcing the measures, Cavallo and President Carlos Menem had a row which resulted in the minister's dismissal.
